8. Investment Program Summary
The program will increase the renewable energy share by developing private sector-led solar photovoltaic power plants of at 
least 1,000-megawatt capacity. The innovative application of the partial credit guarantee and the One ADB approach provide a 
one-stop shop solution for the government to enable private-funded solar power projects at competitive tariffs and provide lower 
the cost of electricity to sustain the economic development. The program is expected to be a landmark transaction accelerating 
the energy transition from fossil fuels to renewables and catalyzing private participation, which can be replicated in other sectors 
and countries.
Impact: Access to clean, sustainable, an affordable energy supply increased (power sector development plan, 2020-2030) 
Outcome: Private sector-led renewable energy generation increased
Outputs: (i)Solar power generation capacity increased,  and (ii)Government's capacity for attracting private investment 
strengthened
Implementation Arrangements: Ministry of Finance and Ministry of Investment and Foreign Trade (MIFT) will be the executing 
agencies.
Project Readiness: The program draws on lessons from ADB-funded private sector solar project in Uzbekistan, which 
benefited from the World Bank's guaranteed letter of credit backed by a credit enhancement product to mitigate NEGU's 
nonpayment risk. The mitigation of the off-taker's payment risks by use of a letter of credit enhanced by international financial 
institutions with AAA credit ratings has been proven effective and efficient in facilitating private investments in the unproven 
market. This structure can be replicated in the transactions anchored on the long-term revenue contracts or service off-taking 
contracts, especially when the state off-takers' creditworthiness is weak or unproven in the market.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to the Republic of Uzbekistan for the Solar Public–Private 
Partnership Investment Program. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will provide a facility 
comprising partial credit guarantees (PCGs) to enhance the standby letter of credit extended by 
a commercial bank to eligible private sector power projects to mitigate the credit risks of the state-
owned off-taker, Joint-Stock Company National Electric Grid of Uzbekistan (NEGU). 
 
2.  The program will increase the renewable energy share by deploying private sector-led 
solar  photovoltaic  power  plants  of  at  least  1,000-megawatt (MW)  capacity.  The  innovative 
application of the PCG and the One ADB approach provide a one-stop shop solution for the 
government to enable private-funded solar power projects at competitive tariffs and lower the cost 
electricity  to  sustain  economic  development.  The  program  is  expected  to  be  a  landmark 
transaction accelerating the energy transition from fossil fuels to renewables and catalyzing 
private participation, which can be replicated in other sectors and countries. 
 
II.  RATIONALE 
 
3.  As one of the fastest-growing economies in the Central and West Asia region, Uzbekistan 
experienced  robust  economic  growth  in  2010–2014,  averaging  more  than  7%.  However, 
unfavorable external economic environment conditions in 2015, such as declining commodity 
prices and the subdued growth of trading partner countries, slowed economic growth from 6.1% 
in 2016 to 4.5% in 2017. In 2017, the country responded by initiating comprehensive economic 
reforms  to  stimulate  demand,  foster  foreign  investment,  and  develop  the  private  sector. 
Uzbekistan has made progress on economic reforms while entrenching macroeconomic stability. 
Major structural reforms include implementing foreign exchange and tax reforms, improving 
macro fiscal management, and restructuring state-owned enterprises. Backed by the gains of the 
structural reforms, Uzbekistan was one of the few countries in the region to record an economic 
expansion in 2020 despite the impact of coronavirus disease (COVID-19), and an economic 
rebound is expected from 2021 onward.1 
 
4.  Sector context. Reliable and affordable electricity supply is critical for driving economic 
growth and socioeconomic development. The power sector has been run by a state-owned utility 
as a monopoly, Joint Stock Company Uzbekenergo, which undertook the combined functions of 
policy setting, planning, investment, daily system operations, and regulation. This structure 
increasingly faced the challenge of meeting fast-growing power demand because of a heavy 
reliance on limited state budget and underinvestment in critical infrastructure. In March 2019, the 
government embarked on comprehensive reforms—starting with creating the Ministry of Energy 
(MOE) as the energy sector ministry, unbundling Uzbekenergo, and liberalizing the market 
structure—to facilitate competition and direct private investments into the power sector. NEGU 
was established in this process as a state-owned entity responsible for the transmission system 
operation and the purchase of electricity from all power generation companies. 
 
5.  The financial situation of the power sector has been weakened by significant technical 
losses, inadequate tariff and unstructured pricing policy, and poor collection rates. While the 
government has continuously rationalized the electricity tariff, with an average adjustment rate of 
5.9% during 2007–2018, the average electricity tariff remained at 81% of the cost recovery level 
in  2020.  This  is  largely  cross-subsidized  by  the  below-market  domestic  gas  cost.  Without 
 
1  International Monetary Fund. 2021. Uzbekistan Staff Concluding Statement of the 2021 Article IV Mission. 
Washington, DC.

2 
adequate  tariff  adjustments—combined  with  measures  to  reduce  technical  losses,  improve 
collection rates, and lower generation costs through competitive energy resources—the fiscal gap 
in the sector would widen, requiring substantial subsidies. The lack of creditworthiness of the 
sector limits financing options for the sector, making it completely reliant on limited state budget 
for major investments. This, in turn, exacerbates underinvestment in the sector. 
 
6.  Access to electricity in Uzbekistan is 100%, but the service quality is poor and unreliable 
because of aging infrastructure and inadequate generation capacity. Unreliable power supply has 
negatively affected people’s livelihoods and businesses’ profitability. More than 32% of firms in 
Uzbekistan identify the lack of reliable electricity as a major constraint to doing business and a 
cause of losses, as outages total 3.0% of enterprises’ annual sales, which is worse than the 
average for Europe and Central Asia.2 Small enterprises suffer more because they cannot afford 
the expensive diesel backup generators. The government forecasts electricity demand to double 
by 2030, and $26 billion is required to add 17 GW of generation capacity to meet this.3 Attracting 
private capital for the adequate investments in the critical infrastructure will be pivotal in resolving 
this development constraint. 
  
7.  Uzbekistan generated 63.6 terawatt-hours of electricity in 2019, more than 85% of which 
was from burning fossil fuels (primarily domestic natural gas). The depleting natural gas resource 
and overdependence on natural gas prompted the country to seek sustainable energy transition 
pathways, in which the introduction of renewable energy will reduce demand pressure and 
rationalize gas consumption for electricity.4 Despite rich solar resources across the country, little 
has been harnessed because of the absence of an integrated energy sector planning and 
enabling regulatory framework for solar development.5 The energy sector is the predominant 
source of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in Uzbekistan. Given Uzbekistan’s commitment to 
combat climate change under the Paris Agreement and long-term energy security risks, the 
promotion of renewable energy is crucial to avoid fossil fuel and curb GHG emissions while 
meeting growing energy demand. 
 
8.  Road  map.  In  April  2020,  the  government  adopted  a  2020–2030  power  sector 
development plan. It also lays out a road map to increase the solar generation capacity from a 
negligible share in 2020 to 5 GW by 2030, accounting for 17% of the total electricity generation, 
and reduce the losses in the transmission and distribution by half to 9% by 2030 (footnote 3). 
Under this road map, the government approved a medium-term renewable energy investment 
program that sets the target to roll out 1.6 GW solar projects by 2025.6 The total investment need 
for this program is estimated at $1.5 billion. The government aims to raise private financing using 
the public–private partnership (PPP) model, in particular an independent power producer (IPP) 
scheme where a private entity will generate electricity for sale to the off-taker and recover its 
investment and operating costs through the electricity tariff. Based on this, the private entity will 
design, finance, build, own, operate, and maintain the solar power plants. The success of IPPs is 
anchored on the long-term tariff payments by the off-taker and the capacity of the government to 
screen and properly design the IPP contractual structure.

9.  The government requested ADB’s assistance to develop a bankable transaction structure, 
draw up replicable contract templates, and identify potential project sites for the solar PPP 
projects. Based on the solar power development road map developed under ADB’s technical 
assistance (TA) and through additional site surveys, multiple promising sites have been identified 
for further development.7 ADB has been assisting the government in designing and running a 
competitive tender process to select a private partner for the first project. Similar competitive 
tendering processes will be conducted for the subsequent tranches with ADB’s TA. A pipeline of 
candidate projects under the program is presented in Table 1.

10.  The MOE and NEGU are developing a 10-year transmission development plan with the 
World  Bank’s  assistance,  which  will  map  out  the  supporting  transmission  infrastructure 
development for the evacuation of power from IPPs. Timely development of the adequate 
supporting transmission infrastructure, to be financed by NEGU and/or the state budget, will 
enable the implementation of a solar investment program. 
 
11.  Policy framework. The government is taking a multifold approach to developing critical 
power infrastructure in Uzbekistan. Its first step was to streamline the policy decision-making and 
integrate energy planning. In March 2019, the government created the MOE as the main state 
authority responsible for charting the sector’s policy and development direction. In April 2020, the 
government approved the first long-term sector development plan (footnote 3), which guides 
policy decisions and promotes a holistic and well-coordinated project selection process. To 
finance power projects, the government has adopted a hybrid policy combining state budgets for 
transmission and distribution, and private capital (through PPPs) for power generation and 
renewable energy. This program will help (i) develop bankable structure replicable for the 
renewable energy projects and (ii) facilitate the mobilization of private investments by addressing 
the credit risks of the off-taker, NEGU. 
 
12.  Uzbekistan adopted its first law regulating PPPs, the PPP Law, in June 2019. This is a 
major  milestone  in  promoting  PPP  projects  and  attracting  foreign  investments  in  major 
infrastructure projects. Before this, the first Renewable Energy Law was enacted in March 2019, 
establishing a sound legal and regulatory framework for investments in renewables. Investors in 
renewable energy will benefit from concessions to undertake projects; privileges of long-term land 
lease agreements; and government support for certain NEGU obligations, including liquidity 
support and termination payments under the power purchase agreement (PPA). These privileges 
are provided up front in the tender packages at the competitive selection process of the private 
partners, and are later embodied in the presidential decrees issued for the respective projects 
and contract documents. The interministerial tender commission, comprising the Ministry of

4 
Finance (MOF), the Ministry of Investments and Foreign Trade (MIFT), and the MOE, governs 
the selection of the private partners. Under this policy framework, a transparent selection process, 
standardized documentation, and support packages will ensure the implementation of the solar 
power development road map (para. 9). 
 
13.  Although  IPPs  have  proved  effective  means  of  bringing  private  capital  into  power 
generation, robust creditworthiness of the off-taker and a sustainable market structure are needed 
to guarantee the successful operation of IPPs over 25 years. The government has been rigorously 
pursuing reform policies designed to address these, including (i) creation of an autonomous tariff 
commission, (ii) adoption of a new cost-reflective tariff methodology, (iii) increased revenue 
collections  through  a  nationwide  advance  metering  program,  and  (iv)  a  stronger  financial 
management system for NEGU. ADB has been playing a leading role along with the European 
Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the World Bank in supporting sector reform with 
targeted policy-based lending operations, policy dialogues, and TA to improve the financial 
situation of the sector value chain. This collaborative support will continue to further improve the 
financial viability and efficiency of the sector. 
 
14.  The use of PCGs will provide a complementary yet critical layer of confidence to investors 
by mitigating NEGU’s credit risks by ensuring tariff payment. As Uzbekistan’s power sector moves 
forward with its major reform agenda, the government and ADB believe that the application of 
PCGs will provide a signal to international investors of the government’s commitment to stabilizing 
and implementing further reforms. The timely offering of PCGs will (i) attract private investors to 
consider investing in a country where it might otherwise have been difficult; (ii) promote fair 
competition among the potential investors; and (iii) allow potential investors to propose the lowest 
possible tariff, even for NEGU, which has not established a payment track record. Those projects 
included in the medium-term renewable investment program, 2021–2025 are priority projects 
benefiting from the incentives extended by the government (para. 12). The policy framework and 
the road map can appropriately and adequately guide the long-term program of investments. 
 
15.  Strategic context. The main objectives of the government’s sector policy are expanding 
generation capacity through renewables, improving security of supply from domestic energy 
resources, and promoting private sector participation. The program is closely aligned with the 
government’s policy directions as well as ADB’s country partnership strategy for Uzbekistan, 
2019–2023, which has the key objective of supporting the country’s movement toward a vibrant 
and inclusive market economy and the transformation of the state’s role.8 The upscaling of 
renewables is the centerpiece of the implementation of Uzbekistan’s commitment under the Paris 
Agreement and GHG reduction goals set in the Nationally Determined Contributions. The program 
is in line with the strategic direction of the operational priorities of ADB’s Strategy 2030 by tackling 
climate  change,  building  climate  and  disaster  resilience,  and  enhancing  environmental 
sustainability.9 In building back from the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, the program 
will help revive the economy by stimulating private investments at scale in the critical and green 
energy infrastructure.   
 
16.  Past assistance and lessons. In 2011, ADB pioneered solar energy development in 
Uzbekistan by developing a solar power development road map (footnote 8). However, solar 
energy development has been stagnant until 2019 because of the monopoly industry structure; 
absence of an enabling regulatory framework; and the lack of national capacity to develop, 
screen, and structure privately funded projects. Starting from 2019, ADB’s upstream support for

9  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila.

5 
power sector reform and policy intervention opened the power market to private investors and 
created an investor-friendly environment.10 ADB’s assistance to the national power sector master 
plan  shifted  the  government  energy  policy  direction  toward  upscaling  renewables  and 
decarbonizing the sector.11 ADB’s downstream support as a transaction advisor to develop a 
bankable transaction structure and replicable templates for the about 1 GW solar PPP investment 
program has proven efficient in attracting private investors and lowering stress on the public 
budget to build large power plants. 
 
17.  The  program  draws  on  lessons  from  ADB-funded  private  sector  solar  project  in 
Uzbekistan, which benefited from the World Bank’s guaranteed letter of credit backed by a credit 
enhancement product to mitigate NEGU’s nonpayment risk.12 The mitigation of the off-taker’s 
payment risks by use of a letter of credit enhanced by international financial institutions with AAA 
credit ratings has been proven effective and efficient in facilitating private investments in the 
unproven market.13 This structure can be replicated in the transactions anchored on the long-term 
revenue  contracts  or  service  off-taking  contracts,  especially  when  the  state  off-takers’ 
creditworthiness is weak or unproven in the market. 
 
III.  THE INVESTMENT PROGRAM 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
18.  The investment program is aligned with the following impact: access to clean, sustainable, 
and affordable energy supply increased (footnote 3). The investment program will have the 
following outcome: private sector-led renewable energy generation increased.14 
 
B.  Outputs 
 
19.  Output 1: Solar power generation capacity increased. Output 1 will deploy at least 
1,000 MW solar photovoltaic power plants through private sector investments by providing short-
term liquidity support backed by PCGs to mitigate NEGU’s off-taker credit risks. The associated 
transmission infrastructure will be transferred by private investors to NEGU upon construction. 
The nonphysical output of project 1 will provide vocational training for solar power related 
business start-up and administration to women in the program area. 
 
20.  Output 2: Government’s capacity for attracting private investment strengthened. 
Capacity development under the MFF will consist of (i) development of bankable PPP structure 
and contract templates, (ii) identification and initial due diligence on subsequent projects and 
tendering, and (iii) development of corporate gender policy for NEGU. ADB will provide separate 
transaction advisory TA to further strengthen the government's capacity in this area.15

21.  Use of facility. These outputs and outcome are best achieved by an MFF approach 
comprising a series of PCGs (facility or guarantee facility).16 The facility approach provides long-
term and timely support to the government for the phased implementation of the road map. The 
series of projects with the support of PCG will create interest in quality investors who may not be 
interested to take the time to bid for one-off projects. This would not only foster competition but 
also establish a market which could be built-on as NEGU establishes its creditworthiness. All 
projects supported by the facility will be substantially similar in nature including the project 
structure, technology, requirements (safeguards and labor), and competitive selection process. 
Framework documents, contract, and procurement templates developed under the MFF will 
efficiently guide the preparation and implementation of subsequent tranches and streamline 
repetitive administrative process. MFF is best suited for the variability of the time taken for bidding 
process, market conditions, and perception of NEGU risk. The competition of the terms (duration 
and payments covered) would be limited with a single guarantee for four projects. Further, 
provision of a sovereign counter-guarantee by the government is determined project by project 
after a winning bidder is selected for the respective project, making a single guarantee with 
sovereign counter-guarantee and indemnity for multiple projects infeasible.    
 
22.  Scope of project 1. Project 1 comprises a standby letter of credit to be issued by a 
commercial bank and be backed by ADB PCG in connection with the 457-megawatt (MW) solar 
photovoltaic power plant and associated 50-kilometer (km) 220-kilovolt (kV) transmission line to 
be constructed in the Sherabad district of Uzbekistan. Abu Dhabi Future Energy Company Public 
Joint Stock Company (Masdar) was selected by the government through international competitive 
bidding supported by ADB at a tariff of $0.018 per kilowatt-hour (kWh) for 25 years, demonstrating 
that the solar photovoltaic plant is the least-cost option in Uzbekistan.17 Project 1 will be the 
largest solar photovoltaic power plant in the Central Asian region once completed.  
 
23.  Innovative approaches. In this program, a standby letter of credit provided by a reputable 
commercial bank will cover the risk if NEGU fails to make timely payments to the IPP up to a 
certain amount. This affords comfort to investors while allowing for lower exposure to ADB 
compared with guaranteeing payment for long-term debt. A $40 million guarantee is expected to 
catalyze more than $1 billion in private investment. The standby letter of credit will be enhanced

IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
31.  Project 1 will be situated in the Sherabad district of Surkhandarya province. Project 1 will 
utilize a proven module technology on a horizontal single-axis mounting structure. These modules 
have a suitable track record and acceptable market-standard characteristics. The capacity of the 
plant is 457 MW and the estimated average output over its lifetime is equal to 995,000 MW-hours 
per annum. The project will include a new 220 kV substation near the plant and about 50 km of 
220 kV lines to connect to the grid at the Surkhan substation. A grid impact assessment identifies 
no  major  risk  with  the  interconnection  of  the  project  to  the  national  grid.  An  independent 
engineering firm jointly engaged by the project company and NEGU will ensure prudent practices 
are applied and all technical requirements are met. The power plant will be designed and operated 
for at least 25 years consistent with the term of the PPA. 
 
32.  Masdar was selected by the government as the private sector partner for project 1 through 
a competitive tender process assisted by ADB.23 Since its inception in 2006, Masdar has 
successfully developed an aggregate 2.7 GW of renewable energy across 30 countries with a 
combined investment of $2.7 billion, including an ADB-funded private sector solar project in 
Uzbekistan (footnote 12). Masdar is equipped with adequate technical and financial capability to 
implement project 1. Masdar will incorporate a project company in Uzbekistan that will be 
responsible for the construction, operation, and maintenance of project 1 during the term of the 
PPA. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
33.  Project 1 is economically viable as demonstrated by its economic internal rate of return of 
18.1% and the net present value of $217.4 million using a 9% discount rate in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects and the Greenhouse Gas Emissions 
Accounting for ADB Energy Project Economic Analysis.24 The main economic benefits relate to 
(i) the meeting of demand growth in the region, (ii) the substitution of electricity generated from 
old gas-fired generation plants, and (iii) the social cost of carbon reduction. Project 1 is also 
financially viable as demonstrated by a financial internal rate of return above the project’s 
weighted average cost of capital, based on financial analysis prepared in accordance with ADB’s 
technical guidance note on Financial Analysis and Evaluation.25 The economic and financial 
viability of project 1 would remain satisfactory even under the adverse scenarios of a reduction in 
project outputs by 16% (based on yield model of 99% probability) and an increase in capital costs 
by 20%. 
 
C.  Governance 
 
34.  Sector governance. The power sector is under the supervision of multiple ministries, 
including the MOE, MOF, and MIFT. The energy policy, the long-term sector development plan, 
and reforms are led by the MOE in coordination with other ministries. The MOF manages the 
performance and sovereign borrowings of the sector state-owned enterprises. The MOF used to 
set  and  adjust  tariffs  and  now  the  interministerial  tariff  council  is  responsible  for  tariff

determination.  Once  the  independent  energy  sector  regulator  is  established,  the  tariff 
determination function will be transferred to the regulator. The MIFT and MOF are responsible for 
the monitoring the implementation of the program. Because of the government’s reform efforts, 
sector governance is improving. Institutional capacity development activities for NEGU, such as 
strengthening  financial  management  capabilities  and  bringing  in  modern  and  transparent 
performance assessment, are underway with ADB support. 
 
35.  Financial  management.  The  pre-mitigation  financial  management  risk  of  NEGU  is 
substantial. NEGU faces several challenges in the transition to International Financial Reporting 
Standards reporting, including staff training and support, and the development of policies and 
procedures. There is an urgent necessity to populate the internal audit unit of NEGU and 
strengthen its role to support business modernization, and budgetary monitoring and information 
provided to management is relatively weak. More generally, corporate governance needs to be 
enhanced, including the formation of an audit committee, the formation of a risk management 
committee, and the development of capacity to produce annual business forecasts covering at 
least 3 years. ADB’s ongoing project and TA for NEGU will continue to strengthen its financial 
management system.26 
 
36.  NEGU has generally been operated on a break-even basis. However, the existing power 
market structure, where NEGU carries out transmission system operation and wholesale service, 
creates  significant  operating  risks.  NEGU  is  highly  exposed  to  the  distribution  company’s 
collection risk, which is better managed with the government’s continued intervention and smart 
meter. Moreover, an increased share of long-term loans on NEGU’s balance sheet, together with 
contingent liabilities through the signing of new PPAs, will create a critical need for asset-based 
remuneration to support loan service capacity and liquidity. The government has committed to 
two key mitigation measures: (i) roll out the smart metering infrastructure by 2022 and (ii) move 
toward a full cost-recovery-base tariff by 2023. The government will implement a transmission 
tariff method and improve NEGU’s operational efficiency and financial condition, including a 
separation of the wholesale service from the transmission system operations. The risk of a call 
on the PCG is assessed to be moderate after these mitigation measures. 
 
37.  Procurement.  All  procurement  supported  by  the  facility  will  conform  to  the  ADB 
Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and Procurement Regulations for ADB 
Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time). 
 
38.  Integrity  due  diligence  was  conducted  on  NEGU  and  the  members  of  its  board  of 
directors.27 They do not appear to constitute a significant or potentially significant integrity risk, 
since no unresolved or substantiated adverse media or other relevant information related to them 
exists. ADB has obtained reasonable assurance that NEGU was not established and is not being 
used for money laundering or terrorism financing in the project jurisdiction. 
 
39.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and NEGU. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the FAM (footnote 18).

D.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
40.  Poverty and social. The ultimate project beneficiaries will be the general population and 
industries in Uzbekistan since the solar power plant will provide electricity to the national grid. 
Reliable and affordable grid-connected electricity will positively affect local business development 
and the delivery of services by schools, clinics, and local governments, which ultimately will 
improve the quality of life. No potential constraints to access the services have been identified. 
Secondary beneficiaries will include the population around the project site. Many unskilled jobs 
for the local population can be created during construction, while a few skilled jobs can be created 
in organizations providing operation and maintenance services for the solar power plant. A 
significant  indirect  effect  on  the  population  is  wider  employment  and  self-employment 
opportunities in such sectors of the economy as catering and services. 
 
41.  Gender.  The  program  is  categorized  some  gender  elements.  Women  are 
underrepresented in Uzbekistan’s energy sector mostly because of lack of necessary education, 
lack of awareness of employment options, limited opportunities for skills development, and 
prevailing stereotypes that regard the energy sector as a high-risk profession not suitable for 
women.  Key  gender  actions  include  (i)  strengthening  NEGU’s  gender-responsive  human 
resources policy, (ii) promoting skills development in developing and structuring energy PPP 
projects, and (iii) conducting vocational trainings for start-up and administration in the project area 
in relation to the solar power projects. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
 
42.  All  projects  will  be  classified  individually  and  category  A  projects  for  environment, 
involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples will not be qualified under the program. An 
environmental  assessment  and  review  framework  and  land  acquisition  and  resettlement 
framework (LARF), which provide guidance on safeguard due diligence to be undertaken for each 
project to be proposed under the program, were prepared. ADB disclosed these frameworks on 
its website in May 2021.28 The government and NEGU have committed to implement, and cause 
the  project  company  to  implement,  the  safeguards  requirement  as  per  the  environmental 
assessment and review framework and LARF. 
 
43.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the safeguard categories 
of project 1 are as follows.29 
 
44.  Environment (category B). Given the construction of solar photovoltaic power plant and 
transmission line, the potential direct, indirect, cumulative, and induced impacts for project 1 are 
anticipated to be of minor magnitude, site-specific, generally reversible, and readily mitigated. 
 
45.  An initial environmental examination (IEE) report for project 1 was cleared by ADB in 2020 
and disclosed on ADB’s website in April 2021. The IEE was prepared for 200 MW capacity of 
solar photovoltaic power generation while 457 MW was proposed afterward (footnote b of Table 
1). The NEGU prepared an addendum to the IEE that confirms that the 457 MW solar plant will 
be constructed within the area of assessment of the original IEE. The addendum also proposes 
some additional mitigation measures to accommodate the increased capacity. The addendum 
was disclosed on ADB’s website in June 2021. Public consultations were conducted for the

construction will be temporary, localized, and moderate impacts (i) within the solar plant site and 
on the corridors of the transmission line and access roads; and (ii) on nearby villages such as 
increased noise, dust levels, vibration, and traffic congestion. There will be minor impacts during 
operation, such as water usage for solar panel cleaning and waste management. The change in 
landscape features and visual impacts will have moderate impacts, while the remaining residual 
impacts are of low significance. The site is located in a modified habitat. A critical habitat status 
is recognized for the southern even-fingered gecko (Alsophylax laevis), which is considered 
critically endangered.30 Some endangered bird species also occur, although none of the species 
meet the threshold requirements for critical habitat. A biodiversity monitoring and evaluation plan 
and a biodiversity action plan, which were prepared as part of the IEE, will be implemented. 
 
46.  Masdar, its project company (para. 32), and contractors will conduct COVID-19 risk 
assessment for the project, and measures to mitigate COVID-19 health risks will be integrated 
into the contractor’s occupational health and safety plans. 
 
47.  Involuntary resettlement (category B). For project 1, the land plot available for the solar 
photovoltaic plant and a new substation is about 600 hectares (ha). The site is mostly barren land 
surrounded by irrigation canals and there are no houses or other residential and commercial 
structures around the location for the solar plant. A social safeguards due diligence report 
disclosed in April 2021 indicates that the solar plant and its substation will not require land 
acquisition and will not cause any economic or physical displacement to nearby residents. The 
land is fully owned by the government and will be made available to the project company through 
a land lease agreement for a duration equal to the term of the PPA. 
 
48.  The 50 km overhead transmission lines will mostly follow the right-of-way along the 
existing transmission lines. An assessment of the tentative route of the overhead transmission 
lines based on preliminary design indicates that 57 privately used land plots and 9 agricultural 
companies may permanently lose 12.96 ha. Another 117.79 ha of their land may be temporarily 
affected during construction. No physical displacement is expected, and all affected persons will 
only lose marginal portions of their agricultural land. To the extent feasible, the route will be altered 
to avoid adverse impacts on privately used land and other assets. Upon completion of the detailed 
design and finalization of the route, the project company will submit to ADB for approval an 
implementation-ready  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  plan  (LARP)  following  the  LARF. 
Commencement  of  civil  works  for  the  transmission  line  will  be  conditional  to  the  full 
implementation of the LARP. The LARP will be implemented following national legislation and 
regulations and ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. 
 
49.  Indigenous  peoples (category  C).  The  project  does  not  have  indigenous  peoples 
impacts as defined by ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. Therefore, the indigenous peoples 
safeguard is not triggered.

metadata.Subject: The program will increase the renewable energy share by deploying private sector-led solar photovoltaic power plants of at least 1,000-megawatt (MW) capacity. The innovative application of the partial credit guarantee (PCG) and the One ADB approach provide a one-stop-shop solution for the government to enable private-funded solar power projects at competitive tariffs and lower the cost of electricity to sustain economic development.The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.This document dated September 2021 is provided for the ADB project 54056-001 in Uzbekistan.
